Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Understanding Mechanisms that Impact the Power Density of an Economical Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell Stack

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this BRIGE award is to understand the permeability of gases through a non-traditional woven structure subjected to non-uniform porosity. This research will provide a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms required to develop a functional graduated material with controlled dimensionality, for use in renewable energy devices. A successful result of this investigation will be a methodology to develop functional materials with unique dimensionality, such that the resistance of a gas to flow may be controlled. Numerical modeling will be conducted to predict how the gases will flow through the graduated medium and to aid with defining the optimal design. Performance analysis will be conducted to evaluate the properties of the woven structure in a functional system.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to a fundamental understanding of gas permeability through a controlled graduated woven structure with non-uniform porosity, which is not well understood. Nontraditional porous media for varying applications have emerged, and such an understanding may impact the design of these systems according to the resulting properties that are desired. The proposed work will contribute to this objective by studying the dimensionality of a woven carbon cloth, which is commonly used in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs). This work will identify key parameters that influence the performance of such systems, leading to innovative stack designs that fundamentally challenge conventional fuel cell configurations and their effectiveness. Coordinated with the technical objective, the outreach goal of implementing a collaborative program coined ELECTRoDE (Educators Leading Energy Conservation and Training Researchers of Diverse Ethnicities) will be employed.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this study was to design a gas diffusion layer (GDL) for a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell with a graduated permeability, and thereby graduating the resistance to flow throughout the GDL.  It has been shown that using conventional materials the GDL exhibits a higher resistance in the through-plane direction, due to the orientation of the small carbon fibers that make up the carbon paper or carbon cloth.  A GDL was designed for an unconventional PEM fuel cell stack, where the reactant gases were supplied through the side of the GDL rather than through flow field channels machined into a bipolar plate.  The effects of changing in-plane and through-plane permeability, GDL thickness and oxygen utilization on the expected current density distribution at the catalyst layer were studied. It was found that a thinner GDL with a lower utilization yields a higher current density on the electrode.  A quantitative metric to measure uniformity of reactant distribution, the ratio of the standard deviation of the current density to the average current density, was introduced, and it was found that while the uniformity of the reactant distribution is independent of thickness of the GDL, it is inversely proportional to utilization. 

Woven gas diffusion layers (GDLs) with varying weave type (plain and twill weave patterns) and tightness were investigated. The in-plane and through-plane air permeability of the woven samples was tested, and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) was used to study the pore structure.  It was found that the twill weave has a higher permeability than the plain weave, which is consistent with literature.  Like non-woven carbon papers, woven GDLs have higher in-plane permeability than through-plane permeability. However, one goal of this work was to determine if higher through-plane than in-plane permeability could be achieved. It has been found that it is possible for twill weave as the tightness decreases.  Consequently, it was found that the percentage of macropores in the woven structure (i.e., GDL) is the driving factor in determining the through-plane air permeability. Water management is a critical parameter that must be characterized in order to determine the feasibility of the overall novel PEMFC design concept. A numerical study using COMSOL was conducted to predict the water saturation of the novel PEMFC that incorporates a flat bipolar plate design.  It was shown that similar results to those reported in the literature are feasible for small sections.  However, as the length increased water saturation increased rapidly resulting in a starved system (poor performance).  In order to compensate for this, additional work is needed to control the gas diffusion or reactant distribution, which could be realized by furthers studying liquid water and water vapor as well as a graduated GDL versus constant permeability, based on varying levels of compression. Successful implementation of this work will lead to lighter weight and lower cost system, and increased production times, because complex bipolar plate channels will no longer be required. 

It is anticipated that implementation of the novel PEMFC concept would consist of incorporating a slender less machined bipolar plate, which would result in time and cost savings.  The predicted machining time, using SURFCam for several bipolar plate configurations, used in PEMFCs, were studied and compared with experimental results. The bipolar plates considered are composed of stainless steel, graphite, and aluminum.  It was found that plates made of the state-of-the-art material, graphite, takes a significant amount more time to machine than the other materials.  This increased machining time leads to an increase in overall cost.  From existing studies it was found that smaller rib widths have...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this study was to design a gas diffusion layer (GDL) for a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell with a graduated permeability, and thereby graduating the resistance to flow throughout the GDL. It has been shown that using conventional materials the GDL exhibits a higher resistance in the through-plane direction, due to the orientation of the small carbon fibers that make up the carbon paper or carbon cloth. A GDL was designed for an unconventional PEM fuel cell stack, where the reactant gases were supplied through the side of the GDL rather than through flow field channels machined into a bipolar plate. The effects of changing in-plane and through-plane permeability, GDL thickness and oxygen utilization on the expected current density distribution at the catalyst layer were studied. It was found that a thinner GDL with a lower utilization yields a higher current density on the electrode. A quantitative metric to measure uniformity of reactant distribution, the ratio of the standard deviation of the current density to the average current density, was introduced, and it was found that while the uniformity of the reactant distribution is independent of thickness of the GDL, it is inversely proportional to utilization. Woven gas diffusion layers (GDLs) with varying weave type (plain and twill weave patterns) and tightness were investigated. The in-plane and through-plane air permeability of the woven samples was tested, and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) was used to study the pore structure. It was found that the twill weave has a higher permeability than the plain weave, which is consistent with literature. Like non-woven carbon papers, woven GDLs have higher in-plane permeability than through-plane permeability. However, one goal of this work was to determine if higher through-plane than in-plane permeability could be achieved. It has been found that it is possible for twill weave as the tightness decreases. Consequently, it was found that the percentage of macropores in the woven structure (i.e., GDL) is the driving factor in determining the through-plane air permeability. Water management is a critical parameter that must be characterized in order to determine the feasibility of the overall novel PEMFC design concept. A numerical study using COMSOL was conducted to predict the water saturation of the novel PEMFC that incorporates a flat bipolar plate design. It was shown that similar results to those reported in the literature are feasible for small sections. However, as the length increased water saturation increased rapidly resulting in a starved system (poor performance). In order to compensate for this, additional work is needed to control the gas diffusion or reactant distribution, which could be realized by furthers studying liquid water and water vapor as well as a graduated GDL versus constant permeability, based on varying levels of compression. Successful implementation of this work will lead to lighter weight and lower cost system, and increased production times, because complex bipolar plate channels will no longer be required. It is anticipated that implementation of the novel PEMFC concept would consist of incorporating a slender less machined bipolar plate, which would result in time and cost savings. The predicted machining time, using SURFCam for several bipolar plate configurations, used in PEMFCs, were studied and compared with experimental results. The bipolar plates considered are composed of stainless steel, graphite, and aluminum. It was found that plates made of the state-of-the-art material, graphite, takes a significant amount more time to machine than the other materials. This increased machining time leads to an increase in overall cost. From existing studies it was found that smaller rib widths have better performance.
